metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Python Polymorphism
The word "polymorphism" means "many forms", and in programming it refers to methods/functions/operators with the same name that can be executed on many objects or classes.
content.html: The word "polymorphism" means "many forms", and in programming it refers to methods/functions/operators with the same name that can be executed on many objects or classes.

content.text: Function Polymorphism
An example of a Python function that can be used on different objects is the len() function.
content.html: An example of a Python function that can be used on different objects is the len() function.

content.text: String
For strings len() returns the number of characters:
content.html: For strings len() returns the number of characters:

content.code_html:
x = "Hello World!"

print(len(x))

content.text: Tuple
For tuples len() returns the number of items in the tuple:
content.html: For tuples len() returns the number of items in the tuple:

content.code_html:
mytuple = ("apple", "banana", "cherry")

print(len(mytuple))

content.text: Dictionary
For dictionaries len() returns the number of key/value pairs in the dictionary:
content.html: For dictionaries len() returns the number of key/value pairs in the dictionary:

content.code_html:
thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}

print(len(thisdict))

content.text: Class Polymorphism
Polymorphism is often used in Class methods, where we can have multiple classes with the same method name.
content.html: Polymorphism is often used in Class methods, where we can have multiple classes with the same method name.

content.text: For example, say we have three classes: Car , Boat , and Plane , and they all have a method called move() :
content.html: For example, say we have three classes: Car, Boat, and Plane, and they all have a method called move():

content.code_html:
class Car:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Drive!")

class Boat:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Sail!")

class Plane:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Fly!")

car1 = Car("Ford", "Mustang")       #Create a Car object
 boat1 = Boat("Ibiza", "Touring 20") #Create a Boat object
 plane1 = Plane("Boeing", "747")     #Create a Plane object
for x in (car1, boat1, plane1):
  x.move()

content.text: Look at the for loop at the end. Because of polymorphism we can execute the same method for all three classes.
content.html: Look at the for loop at the end. Because of polymorphism we can execute the same method for all three classes.

content.text: Inheritance Class Polymorphism
What about classes with child classes with the same name? Can we use polymorphism there?
content.html: What about classes with child classes with the same name? Can we use polymorphism there?

content.text: Yes. If we use the example above and make a parent class called Vehicle , and make Car , Boat , Plane child classes of Vehicle , the child classes inherits the Vehicle methods, but can override them:
content.html: Yes. If we use the example above and make a parent class called Vehicle, and make Car, Boat, Plane child classes of Vehicle, the child classes inherits the Vehicle methods, but can override them:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class Vehicle:  def __init__(self, brand, model):    
    self.brand = brand    self.model = model  
    def move(self):    print("Move!")class 
    Car(Vehicle):  passclass Boat(Vehicle):  def 
    move(self):    print("Sail!")class 
    Plane(Vehicle):  def move(self):    
    print("Fly!")car1 = Car("Ford", "Mustang")       #Create a Car object
    boat1 = Boat("Ibiza", "Touring 20") #Create a Boat objectplane1 = 
    Plane("Boeing", "747")     #Create a Plane objectfor x in (car1, boat1, 
    plane1):  print(x.brand)  print(x.model)  x.move()

 def move(self):    print("Move!")class

content.code_html:
class Vehicle:
  def __init__(self, brand, model):
    self.brand = brand
    self.model = model

  def move(self):
    print("Move!")

class Car(Vehicle):
  pass

class Boat(Vehicle):
  def move(self):
    print("Sail!")

class Plane(Vehicle):
  def move(self):
    print("Fly!")

car1 = Car("Ford", "Mustang")       #Create a Car object
 boat1 = Boat("Ibiza", "Touring 20") #Create a Boat object
plane1 = Plane("Boeing", "747")     #Create a Plane object

for x in (car1, boat1, plane1):
  print(x.brand)
  print(x.model)
  x.move()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class Vehicle:  def __init__(self, brand, model):    
    self.brand = brand    self.model = model  
    def move(self):    print("Move!")class 
    Car(Vehicle):  passclass Boat(Vehicle):  def 
    move(self):    print("Sail!")class 
    Plane(Vehicle):  def move(self):    
    print("Fly!")car1 = Car("Ford", "Mustang")       #Create a Car object
    boat1 = Boat("Ibiza", "Touring 20") #Create a Boat objectplane1 = 
    Plane("Boeing", "747")     #Create a Plane objectfor x in (car1, boat1, 
    plane1):  print(x.brand)  print(x.model)  x.move()

content.text: Child classes inherits the properties and methods from the parent class.
content.html: Child classes inherits the properties and methods from the parent class.

content.text: In the example above you can see that the Car class is empty, but it inherits brand , model , and move() from Vehicle .
content.html: In the example above you can see that the Car class is empty, but it inherits brand, model, and move() from Vehicle.

content.text: The Boat and Plane classes also inherit brand , model , and move() from Vehicle , but they both override the move() method.
content.html: The Boat and Plane classes also inherit brand, model, and move() from Vehicle, but they both override the move() method.

content.text: Because of polymorphism we can execute the same method for all classes.
content.html: Because of polymorphism we can execute the same method for all classes.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
True or False. One object cannot have a method with the same name as another object's method.
content.html: True or False. One object cannot have a method with the same name as another object's method.

content.question: True or False. One object cannot have a method with the same name as another object's method.
